title: Lesson 28: Pseudoinverse and Rank-Deficient Systems
objectives: Understand the pseudoinverse for any matrix

cards.front: What is the Moore-Penrose pseudoinverse \( A^+ \)?
cards.back:
The unique matrix satisfying four conditions:

  1. \( AA^+A = A \)
  2. \( A^+AA^+ = A^+ \)
  3. \( (AA^+)^T = AA^+ \)
  4. \( (A^+A)^T = A^+A \)

Generalizes the inverse to any matrix (including non-square and singular).

cards.front: How do you compute the pseudoinverse using SVD?
cards.back:
If \( A = U\Sigma V^T \), then:

\( A^+ = V\Sigma^+ U^T \)

Where \( \Sigma^+ \) inverts non-zero singular values:

\( \sigma_i^+ = \begin{cases} 1/\sigma_i & \sigma_i > 0 \\ 0 & \sigma_i = 0 \end{cases} \)

cards.front: What does \( A^+ \) give for an overdetermined system \( A\vec{x} = \vec{b} \)?
cards.back:
\( \hat{x} = A^+ \vec{b} \) is the least-squares solution.

It minimizes \( ||A\vec{x} - \vec{b}||_2 \).

For full column rank: \( A^+ = (A^T A)^{-1} A^T \)

cards.front: What does \( A^+ \) give for an underdetermined system?
cards.back:
\( \hat{x} = A^+ \vec{b} \) is the minimum-norm solution.

Among all solutions to \( A\vec{x} = \vec{b} \), it has the smallest \( ||\vec{x}||_2 \).

For full row rank: \( A^+ = A^T(AA^T)^{-1} \)

cards.front: What is the minimum-norm least-squares solution?
cards.back:
For any system \( A\vec{x} = \vec{b} \), \( A^+ \vec{b} \) gives the solution that:

  1. Minimizes \( ||A\vec{x} - \vec{b}||_2 \) (closest to \( \vec{b} \))
  2. Among those, minimizes \( ||\vec{x}||_2 \) (smallest solution)

This handles all cases: overdetermined, underdetermined, rank-deficient.

cards.front: What is the relationship between \( AA^+ \) and \( A^+A \)?
cards.back:
\( AA^+ \) = projection onto \( \text{Col}(A) \)

\( A^+A \) = projection onto \( \text{Row}(A) \)

Both are orthogonal projection matrices (symmetric and idempotent).

cards.front: What happens when a matrix is rank-deficient?
cards.back:
The least-squares problem has infinitely many solutions (non-unique).

The pseudoinverse picks the unique minimum-norm solution.

Geometrically: project onto column space, then pick the shortest preimage.

cards.front: How do you handle near-zero singular values in practice?
cards.back:
Use truncated pseudoinverse: set \( \sigma_i^+ = 0 \) for \( \sigma_i < \epsilon \).

This is regularization against numerical instability.

Small singular values cause large, unreliable components in \( A^+ \).

cards.front: What is the pseudoinverse of a diagonal matrix?
cards.back:
Invert non-zero diagonal entries, leave zeros as zeros:

\( D = \text{diag}(\sigma_1, ..., \sigma_r, 0, ..., 0) \)

\( D^+ = \text{diag}(1/\sigma_1, ..., 1/\sigma_r, 0, ..., 0) \)

Transpose the shape if \( D \) is not square.

cards.front: Why is the pseudoinverse important for MI?
cards.back:
It enables:

  • Solving linear probes even with rank-deficient features
  • Interpreting linear readouts robustly
  • Finding minimal interventions/edits
  • Handling cases where exact solutions don't exist
